ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Stats and R studio basics
A solid base of the foundations of statistics
Introductory statistics knowledge
I learned mainly how to functionally use R, along with statistical concepts and tests that I can use in the future.
I learned the basics of statistics (e.g. performing various hypothesis tests, creating confidence intervals, etc.) and how to apply it to problems.
all basic introductory stats concepts
I developed an understanding of basic statistical reasoning.
I got a better sense of how to understand data and what various statistics mean.
Great intro to statistics learning a strong theory foundation and also more basic application in R
Just a general introduction to statistics and interpreting statistics with R.
Through this course, I was able to learn how to use R and R Studio in order to analyze data sets and make inferences about larger populations based off of the results.
I learned about the basics of statistical analysis and inferential statistics/hypothesis testing
I learned basic statistical inference and basic R programming

I learned the basics of descriptive statistics and inferential statistics via hypothesis testing and creating confidence intervals. While the beginning of the course is spent on descriptive statistics, the majority of the course is spent learning different methods of hypothesis testing (both randomization/permutation methods and parametric methods). I also learned the basics of the R programming language.
I developed a basic knowledge of Statistics. In particular, I learned the basics of descriptive statistics, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, and other inferential statistics.
Basic statistics and coding in R.
stats stuff
How to do basic economics.
I gained an understanding of data analysis concepts as well as an understanding of how to code in R.
Didnt know anything about stat so this was a good intro
Basic statistical concepts and applications
I learned how to use rstudio and learned some of the basic concepts of statistics.
I learned how to use R and do some basic statistical analysis
I took this class to get an intro to R and that's what I received. I feel competent enough to work with it in my research now, even if I may need help running the more specialized lab-specific code.
I learned a lot of introductory R and some basic stats theory.
how to use data to ask a question, run simulations, and come to a conclusion
Basic statistics skills
Learned how to use R and essential concepts in stats!
This class was a great introduction to data analysis.
How to use R studio to analyze data
basic overview of descriptive and inferential statistics

A basic introduction to stats in R-- visually representing data, measuring spread/means/etc, lots of hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. Enough to take a stab at answering basic questions about a data set (ex "do younger people statistically vote less" or similar)
"

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Flexible online format

Strengths: great Professor. He cares a lot about the class and the students. He also developed multiple ways of engaging with the class apart from the usual tools. For example, I liked how he used edstem.org to post questions. This made the course easier to follow.
The class videos were far too long
Topics toward the end of the class were not explained well. Student's should have more independence in learning R and there should be more of a focus on teaching statistics theory.

I thought this course was very thorough and in depth. Professor Meyers made sure that he was clear and organized with all of the material and I appreciated that. I was frustrated more often than not with the course though. The Canvas quiz format with participation questions ensured that we were following along with lectures and understanding material, however, I saw no benefit from these survey questions. I received zero feedback on the work I did and found that these surveys resulted in lectures taking much longer than a lecture should in a normal live-lecture format. I wouldn't mind this if I received feedback for my work, however, with the lack of feedback I found I was just answering the questions just to answer them and really not processing information. The questions became an added pressure throughout the semester because they would hurt my participation grade if I didn't complete them. I think the questions had an adverse effect for me than what was intended and I hope Professor Meyers reevaluates using them in the future.

This course was great! Professor Meyers was informative, caring, and genuinely wanted us to have an as-least-stressed-as-possible semester. The material was presented in a palatable way, allowing for a greater depth of understanding and ability to master the skills required in R to succeed in this course.

Because of the asynchronous component of the class, I felt very disengaged. I found it difficult to make sure I was truly learning the material, even though I worked collaboratively with other students and asked questions on Ed Discussions.

Strengths: The workload was not too rigorous, and the problem sets allowed for application of the lessons we learned in class. 

Weaknesses: The course as a whole was rather disorganized, and it did not seem to be structured to be conducive to student learning. The content was basic, which is understandable given this is the most introductory course in statistics, but at times, it felt like I was not really maximizing the opportunity to learn as a student. The midterm exam was scheduled the morning immediately after a break day, which was strictly advised against by the administration, and when asked on Ed, the teaching staff dismissed these concerns saying that the exam "had already been scheduled" (as had every single break day and the Yale academic calendar). Instead, the professor provided the option to take the exam two days early with less than 24-hours notice, the same day that our campus faced a major tragedy. Despite each Canvas quiz asking for student feedback, it felt as though nothing was changed with regards to the course, and frankly, I was immensely disappointed by the end of the semester. I wish I had better used 1 of my 36 credits at Yale.
I realized this semester that don't learn well with asynchronous courses. I also felt like the use of R distracted from learning the actual statistical concepts.

Strength was doing the lectures and having them recorded to rewatch later on. I honestly thought the hw should have been a little harder. I felt like it was too straight forward to get the overarching concepts, but it wasn't until the end of the semester that we starting overlapping in concepts more. The exams in my opinion were much harder than the homework, and I was not prepared for the first midterm.

Strengths: online learning was generally smooth, and content flowed in a logical manner. Recorded lectures were engaging!
Weaknesses: At time class was a bit disorganized, as well as sometimes being a disconnect between lectures and homework.

In the virtual format, the format of the lectures was effective. They were delivered through canvas quizzes that allowed us to follow along and do practice questions relating to the lecture videos. It was taught asynchronously, meaning we could watch the videos when we wanted

Strengths: The material is mostly well-paced, the psets were fair, and the recorded lectures were still fun somehow

Weaknesses: the only problem with pacing is that the last few topics felt a little rushed and there was a big gap between psets and exams

Strengths - the course moves at a fairly slow but steady pace. The material remains interesting without being too challenging. It is a great intro course. Weaknesses - Don't expect to learn too much R in this course. You will only learn the very basics.

This course doubled the amount of expected class time, having recorded lectures that were given in a quiz format. It was very poorly formatted in that students could only learn material through quiz questions that they often got wrong or did not know how to do.
The asynchronous learning was great.
Definitely felt as though the class could have had a little more structure in the second half as the material sort of became jumbled and harder to keep track of.
Lecture and hw were okay. The exams were generally harder.
I felt that the quiz/flipped classroom structure got slightly redundant at times particularly because the canvas quizzes didnt have any stakes
I think it was nice that it was asynchronous but also that made it less engaging because practically no one came to the live office hours or discussions. In person, the class will be more engaging.

This course is a good introduction to R, but falls short of actually teaching statistics. I don't feel as though I've gained any statistics intuition, and the structure of the course was frustrating at times.

I feel like this class was one of the only intro courses I've taken that actually felt like an intro course. Unlike courses such as the intro bio sequence, stats 100 does not assume any prior knowledge of R/statistics and moves at what I considered an entirely reasonable and appropriate pace. The homework was very representative of what we learned in class and I think contributed well to my learning, but the tests were difficult.

The course was decently organized, and did teach me a lot about introductory level R.

On the other hand, much of the material on the midterm and final was disconnected from what we spent our classes learning. We'd learn a bit of theory in class, never get any reinforcement on it in the homework which focused on application, and then get slammed on the midterm and finals by theoretical questions we were not well prepared for. Additionally, the course was pretty un-engaging overall I get that basic Stats is never going to fascinate,  but the structure of recorded lectures made a less than interesting subject a real slog.

strength: awesome material, i liked the format of recorded lectures in small bits. I also enjoyed the quiz structure that had you follow along by answering questions. Ed discussions was also very useful.

weakness: During exams, the initial time was not flexible for people taking thus course from different timezones.
The course is organized and taught pretty well, but may benefit from having things like collaborative sessions for students

The pre-recorded lectures allowed students to work through the material at their own pace. I found the review questions incredibly useful because they helped me learn AND retain the concepts from lecture. The problem sets were very fair. I'd make two major suggestions for the course: (1) a faster turnaround for graded assignments (problem sets often took several weeks and I would thus make similar mistakes on subsequent PSets) (2) a faster lecture pace at the beginning of the course and a slower pace at the end of the course.

I think the quiz format of the lectures was a major negative for me since it meant my first introduction to the material was quite tiring and took a lot of time. This was basically like doing a small problem set with each lecture, and while I'm sure it was good for active learning it did make the class much more work than a normal lecture. The constant "Greek" metaphor seemed a bit overdone and weak, it was super helpful for recall. That said, Ethan's use of many, many example problems was super great. The whole team, including TA's, was very responsive to questions on Ed discussions. We didn't get a ton of information on the format of the tests until the week of, but they were all very fair and reasonable. The actual lectures were well presented and simple to understand. The Psets are reasonable and well designed. The final project was great.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the practices succeeded
Asynchronous classes were fine, but there should have been a better established lesson plan for the synchronous classes.

I think this class was very well organized for COVID with the utilization of Canvas quizzes and modules for each class. It made attending a virtual class effortless and helped me in my learning process. I loved that I had many opportunities to speak to Professor Meyers and other TAs when I had questions . Ed Discussions were also a great tool for me in getting help, and my questions were answered very quickly by Professor Meyers so I really appreciated the platform. However, again the participation grade in the course required students to ask and answer questions on Ed Discussion, which again turned something that was suppose to be for our benefit and make our lives easier, to something that was a serious pressure throughout the course. I didn't find myself having enough questions to fulfill the participation requirement with Ed and couldn't answer questions for other students because Professor Meyers would answer them too quickly. By the end I was asking empty questions just to get my participation points and I saw many students doing the same. This made Ed filled with an excessive number of repeated questions and truly unhelpful questions. To put this problem in perspective, my other similarly sized classes that used Ed had 62 and 152 questions, while S&DS 100 had over 500.

The asynchronous component allowed people to complete the classes on their own time, but I felt disconnected from the material and my classmates as a result. I would have preferred live, synchronous lecture. I also didn't love the Canvas Quiz format for classes because it required having multiple tabs open so I didn't need to scroll much.
N/A

Even though I didn't enjoy the asynchronous component, the review sessions were helpful, especially when we cut down to one a week. When we were doing two a week, I felt like there was a lot of wasted/filler time, but this wasn't as much of an issue when we reduced it to one session a week.
I thought eventing worked out including class and the exams. I would have preferred the midterm also an r document similar to final or our homeworks rather than the canvas quiz.
Pretty much most things succeeded! Lectures recorded online worked well for the course.
Office hours on zoom are just unbearable
The lecture format using canvas quizzes was effective. Ed discussion was great for asking/answering questions we had.
It was hard to always stay engaged with a class without live lectures.

I am not sure how this course will be taught when in person, but the asynchronous lectures were not as engaging as the live lectures I have had in other classes. They did allow for more flexibility and the ability to watch at different speeds, but they were not the most stimulating.
I think the canvas quiz format was fairly conducive to learning.
The recorded clases were great.

The quizzes were a great way to mitigate the problems of covid although they often exceeded the time I thought this class would take up as the 75 minute watch time that was estimated often exceeded 2-2.5 hours for tougher concepts.
Having the lectures recorded was great.
I really didn't like the pre-recorded format with the Canvas quizzes! A live lecture (recorded of course) would be much better.
The option to review material synchronously as well as completing the bulk of the class material asynchronously I think worked well
I think the office hours held by Professor Meyers were helpful and more engaging than the recorded lectures.
The recorded lectures allowed for flexibility, which was nice.
Recorded lectures are a disaster for engagement with a course, and in-class review sessions at 9am are understandably not of much use.
Succeeded: Ed discussions was very useful. Recorded lectures was also great because I could watch at my own pace.
I like that the lectures were divided into short segments as it made it easier to watch compared to an hour long video. I also appreciate that actual class time served as office hours.
The recorded lectures + review questions worked out really well. I wouldn't suggest any major changes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It helps you build a strong base in statistics.
Sure for an overview of statistic and R

I think everyone should take introductory statistics. It is an important subject that has applications everywhere in the world: politics, maths, sciences, humanities, etc. However, I cannot recommend taking this class with Professor Meyers. This was my second time taking statistics (I did AP Stats in high school) and my experience the second time around was much weaker than the first. I found myself often doing busy work with Professor Meyers and not spending my time learning meaningfully as I did in high school with my AP Stats teacher. I will admit that I was perhaps bored because I had already seen most of the material taught before, but that doesn't deny the fact that this class had a lot of unnecessary busy work associated with it that made it one of my most time consuming courses (more time consuming than S&DS 230). Bottom line is that you should take statistics level 100 because the material is vitally important in the modern world, but I would only take it with Professor Meyers if you need a lot of repetition and reviewing of concepts throughout the course (the busy work I mentioned).

Yes! I thought it was a great introduction to statistics, although I took AP Statistics in high school, so the material may have been a little easier for me. Professor Meyers was informative, caring, and genuinely wanted us to have an as-least-stressed-as-possible semester. The material was presented in a palatable way, allowing for a greater depth of understanding and ability to master the skills required in R to succeed in this course.

I wouldn't recommend this course, as it stands. I hope that in non-pandemic times, this class would be better and more suited to student learning and engagement. I found that taking this class asynchronously was boring.
Honestly, just take something more interesting.
If you're looking for an intro statistics class, this one was good!
Yes! this is a great intro to stats from someone who has never taken a stats course in their life!
Yes! Great intro to stat and R, both essential skills in many fields of study!
Yes
Yes, I think this is a good intro level course to take.
I would definitely take this if you want a chill introduction to stats. The workload is manageable and the psets are fairly straight forward.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning about Statistics and has not taken any courses in Statistics before. If you have taken Statistics courses (e.g. in high school, in another semester), there are probably more advanced classes that would be better for you. Otherwise, this is a fine introduction.
Yes - this is a great intro Stats course. It is not too difficult, but it is still interesting. The Prof is very engaging, and this course sets you up well to take other Stats courses.
Nah
Yes, it is a great class to learn how to do statistics.

Yes, If you want to take a first-class in data analysis and get a grasp of an easy computer language this is the way to go. This class gives a great basic understanding of a lot of interesting things.
Yes! It taught me what I needed to know, and it wasn't a massive time commitment.

Yes-- this class is essentially exactly what you sign up for. It's perfect for someone with zero statistics background or anyone who needs a QR but wouldn't consider themselves a QR type of person. It's difficult at points, and the work is very constant, so best not fall behind. But at the end of the day, it's a pretty standard course. Prof Meyers had a strange Covid plan (including mandatory quizzes for every recorded lecture), but I don't foresee this becoming an issue in the future.
It is definitely a good primer for statistical concepts which have applications across post fields. As such, I would definitely encourage people to take a stats course if not this one
I think its valuable for a baseline understanding of statistics for whatever field youre going into and its a nice introduction to coding using R.

I would not recommend this course. It was difficult to actually develop statistical intuition and the course was very dependent on the R programming language. I appreciate it as an intro to R, but as a statistics course, it should be reworked.
Yes! Take this if you want an introduction to statistics (and/or R, like I did) that moves at a good pace and doesn't give unreasonable amounts of work each week.

If you want to learn introductory statistics and R, this class is a decent way to do that. It won't be fun, and it won't be that interesting, but these are very valuable skills. The course work isn't hard, but be wary of the midterm and final which can mess up your grade if you aren't careful. Take the class if you feel you need to or want the skillset, but maybe shop around other Stats courses too like YData or the SDS 101-109 series.
Yes, statistics helps ground your intuition and questions in data. Very important
Yes, take this course if you are interested in statistics or need it as a prerequisite class
If you need a gutty qr
Yes! Prof Meyers is kind, and this is a great, low stress intro.
Yes

Yes! This class is a great way to get a basic understanding of some principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. There is a little bit of coding involved, but prior experience with coding is absolutely NOT needed. The exams are fair and problem sets help reinforce lecture material without being too burdensome. Moreover, the abundance of TAs/peer tutors makes it really easy to ask questions about the material or coding errors.
Yes, but keep up with the lectures. Falling behind kills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: in-person lab
and in person classes
Asynchronous virtual classes

This course took advantage of Canvas quizzes to organize recorded lecture material and added in various participation questions that followed with the lectures to make sure students are understanding the material.
Asynchronous, pre-recorded lectures with two optional in-person sessions
live sessions/office hours twice a week
N/A
We had to watch recorded lectures twice a week, and there was an optional review session/office hours twice a week during the scheduled class time.
N/A
In-person office hours that were held during our given class times, recorded lectures were also interactive with questions and exercises
Canvas Quizzes
There was also a zoom meeting to review material twice a week during class time.
Review periods.
Recorded videos and questions to ensure retention as well as an in-person class for those who wanted to review concepts or go further into the material.
Also could attend lecture
Canvas quizzes
Office hours over zoom in addition to asynchronous recorded lectures
Asynchronous recorded lectures
Recorded lecture, with optional in-class zoom review sessions.
office hours in person
Recorded lecture and live virtual office hours during the actual class time
Weekly quizzes
optional live virtual lecture, problem sets, final project
Recorded lectures, which were given in the form of quizzes on Canvas with questions for the student, plus synchronous-optional class sessions.
